articles.headline: Assets Frozen for Brother of Madoff
articles.snippet: The trustee already handling the liquidation of Bernard L. Madoff’s New York brokerage business has been given control of his stake in his London operation.
articles.abstract: The trustee already handling the liquidation of Bernard L. Madoff’s New York brokerage business has been given control of his stake in his London operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months in the background, Peter B. Madoff is suddenly being pulled into the spotlight focused on his older brother, Bernard L. Madoff, who has confessed to running a global Ponzi scheme.

articles.headline: Afghan Strikes by Taliban Get Pakistan Help, U.S. Aides Say
articles.snippet: The support consists of money, military supplies and planning guidance to Taliban commanders who are gearing up to confront a larger force in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The support consists of money, military supplies and planning guidance to Taliban commanders who are gearing up to confront a larger force in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Taliban’s widening campaign in southern Afghanistan is made possible in part by direct support from operatives in Pakistan’s military intelligence agency, despite Pakistani government promises to sever ties to militant groups fighting in Afghanistan, according to American government officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: When Laptops Go Light
articles.snippet: Netbooks have slow processors, tiny screens and are good at handling e-mail. Why are they so popular?
articles.abstract: Netbooks have slow processors, tiny screens and are good at handling e-mail. Why are they so popular?
articles.lead_paragraph: Did you hear about the new Hilton NanoSuites? You get a single bed in a room about 8 feet square  and no shower.

articles.headline: Japan’s Small Exporters Are Hit Hardest
articles.snippet: Small firms, withering in the downturn, employ almost 90 percent of workers in Japan’s manufacturing sector.
articles.abstract: Small firms, withering in the downturn, employ almost 90 percent of workers in Japan’s manufacturing sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAITAMA, Japan — Most people who own an iPhone, a Prius or a Nintendo Wii have never heard of Porite, but this small company outside Tokyo makes a crucial part of their toys’ vital organs.

articles.headline: Cities Deal With a Surge in Shantytowns
articles.snippet: Reminiscent of the Great Depression, encampments of homeless people are growing in such cities as Fresno, Calif.
articles.abstract: Reminiscent of the Great Depression, encampments of homeless people are growing in such cities as Fresno, Calif.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — As the operations manager of an outreach center for the homeless here, Paul Stack is used to seeing people down on their luck. What he had never seen before was people living in tents and lean-tos on the railroad lot across from the center.

articles.headline: Paid Handsomely to Stay
articles.snippet: Despite the furor over the bonuses paid by A.I.G., executives at more than a dozen other firms that received government money stand to collect similar bonuses.
articles.abstract: Despite the furor over the bonuses paid by A.I.G., executives at more than a dozen other firms that received government money stand to collect similar bonuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before the furor over pay at A.I.G., most Americans probably had never heard of a retention bonus. But like C.D.O. and credit-default swap, the term, a bit of sugar-coated corporate-speak, is quickly entering the popular lexicon.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Jonathan D. Glater

articles.headline: Online Age Quiz Is a Window for Drug Makers
articles.snippet: Takers of the popular online RealAge test are handing out valuable data to drug companies.
articles.abstract: Takers of the popular online RealAge test are handing out valuable data to drug companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans yearn to be young. So it is little wonder that RealAge, which promises to help shave years off your age, has become one of the most popular tests on the Internet.

articles.headline: Hurt by Economy, Europeans Vent Their Anger
articles.snippet: A former British banker’s home was vandalized, and French workers barricaded a factory manager in his office.
articles.abstract: A former British banker’s home was vandalized, and French workers barricaded a factory manager in his office.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Tempers are flaring across Europe as the economic pain deepens and more people lose their jobs.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and Matthew Saltmarsh

articles.headline: Geithner to Outline Major Overhaul of Finance Rules
articles.snippet: Officials said the plan, which will be unveiled Thursday, will subject hedge funds and traders of exotic financial products to governmental supervision.
articles.abstract: Officials said the plan, which will be unveiled Thursday, will subject hedge funds and traders of exotic financial products to governmental supervision.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration will detail on Thursday a wide-ranging plan to overhaul financial regulation by subjecting hedge funds and traders of exotic financial instruments, now among the biggest and most freewheeling players on Wall Street, to potentially strict new government supervision, officials said.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Louise Story

articles.headline: Battles Over Reform Plan Lie Ahead
articles.snippet: Calls by the Treasury to expand the government’s powers to regulate financial institutions were publicly met with support but are likely to provoke intense resistance from the industry.
articles.abstract: Calls by the Treasury to expand the government’s powers to regulate financial institutions were publicly met with support but are likely to provoke intense resistance from the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Outlining a far-reaching proposal on Thursday to rebuild the nation’s broken system of financial regulation, the Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, fired the opening salvo in what is likely to be a marathon battle.
